intro: Omphalolappula concava, commonly known as the bladderleaf bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Campanulaceae family. It is native to eastern North America, where it thrives in moist, woodland habitats. The plant is characterized by its basal rosette of heart-shaped, waxy leaves and clusters of bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds. Due to its habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many regions.
